1.2: platform maintains a searchable global directory of the scientific projects, initiatives and resources available on the 17 goals of Sustainable Development set by the United Nations.

text.2: The Socioscope is free, non-profit, public-funded, and GDPR compliant.

about.subtitle:
Societal impacts and aftermath of Covid-19:
A global searchable directory

content.blazon: Some partnering institutions (funding institutions, learned societies, etc.) can signal projects that have undergone a peer-review process. They can stamp these projects on The Socioscope with their blazon, which is a label that vets the project with the institution’s cognitive authority.
content.expectations: Contributors should be straight to the point of what they are doing and what is the added value of their project. The abstract should be brief, informative and self-explanatory, very explicit about the problem addressed, the research question, the methodology, the data set, the team, and the expected outcome. A link can be provided to a webpage containing a more detailed description and material.

gdpr.1: Yes. We respect GDPR/ePR rules and even more.
gdpr.2: We do not track users or store any information outside of the project definition scope. A basic and anonymous browser fingerprint is stored only to estimate unique project views and improve our project ranking feature. We do not disclose or sell email addresses or any other personal information.
gdpr.3: We do not use cookies except for those of
gdpr.4: in order to protect our forms against spam and abuse.
gdpr.5: We welcome every suggestion or advice, so please do not hesitate to

howInstitution.1: Provide a short abstract describing your organization
howInstitution.2: Provide the names of 5 potential referents
howInstitution.3: Ask your members/affiliates to register their relevant projects on The Socioscope
howInstitution.4: Send all of the above information at
howInstitution.5: We will get back to you in a matter of days

howProject.2: with basic information. To ensure visibility to your project, carefully select keywords for disciplines, themes and types of project.
howProject.3: Verify your contact email and get your URL to manage your project through a simple and secured token-based process, fully GDPR/ePR compliant.
howProject.4: Edit your project information (new team member, new results, new publication, new funding) at any time.

howReferent.1: The Socioscope referents are senior scientists with vast experience; they operate pro bono for the benefit of the community. A list of
howReferent.2: is published on the The Socioscope website. The International Scientific Advisory Board validates admission to the The Socioscope communities of referents.

promote.1: First, thank you very much for your support!
promote.2: If you want to promote The Socioscope as an initiative, you can use our social media channels. Their links can be found in the footer of every page. You can also use the resources of our
promote.3: If you want to promote a particular project of The Socioscope, you can use the social share widgets of the share button
promote.4: . The short The Socioscope URL with the The Socioscope-ID number of your project is also handy as an email footer.
promote.5: On every The Socioscope project page. If you plan to share a project with a large audience, we advise you to give a heads up to the project contact using the "Email this project contact" button of the related project page.

whoMembers.1: The Socioscope is an edited global directory of projects, initiatives and resources that functions as an open platform open for all to browse: researchers, funders, governments, media, and the general public alike.
whoMembers.2: We have three type of contributors:
whoMembers.4: who register their project on The Socioscope, update it, receive alerts and offers for collaboration and funding.
whoMembers.5: who are aware of new projects in their domain, screen them, flag those they consider most innovative and interesting.
whoMembers.6: that request their members to register projects, publish calls and fund projects, stamp their blazon on flagged projects, provide high-level scholars as referents.

whoReferent.3: for the benefit of the community. A
whoReferent.5: is published on the The Socioscope website. The International
whoReferent.6: validates admission to the The Socioscope communities of referents.

whyInstitution.1: Participate in a global effort to solve the crisis
whyInstitution.2: Showcase the work of your members and affiliates
whyInstitution.3: Put your blazon on the projects you vet or support
whyInstitution.4: Publish your calls and important initiatives
whyInstitution.5: Use The Socioscope as a brick of infrastructure to follow the projects of your members and affiliates. These bricks of service (tag, search, follow) are provided for free.

whyProject.1: Give more visibility to your project via a dedicated webpage on {0} with a link to your own.
whyProject.2: Be notified of and get access to projects matching your interests (by browsing the project list, getting contact requests and update alerts).
whyProject.3: Get a time-stamped {0}-ID that enables to be cited even before you publish.
whyProject.4: Get feedback from The Socioscope referents and have your project featured.
whyProject.5: Attract visibility from funders to support your project

process.text1: The Socioscope features resources that have been filtered, tagged, and indexed, screened by bots first and validated by human experts second.
process.text2: Contributors upload the information about their project themselves with a very simple form on the The Socioscope website.
process.text4: Beverli, our Bot for email verification, will send an email to the address that the contributor mentioned as the contact person with a link. The project will not be published until the project contact person has clicked on the link.
process.text6: Filipeda (another bot) will email confirmation to the project contact person
process.text61: The project contact person should keep this link: it is their token of access to edit their webpage.
process.text8: After publication, The Socioscope secretariate will review the project and might request precisions or recommend edits. If a serious issue is found (i.e. ethical issues or strong methodological reservations), the project will go unpublished (the project contact person can appeal at
process.text9: As projects are often work-in-progress, updates are encouraged. The project contact person can use the secure link provided in Filipeda’s email message to edit the project page.
process.text10: with a link to edit or delete it
process.test51: Once the email address has been verified, the The Socioscope project webpage is published.

referents.title: Referents
referents.text: The Socioscope referents are senior scientists with vast experience, selected by the Scientific Advisory Board; they operate pro bono for the benefit of the community. Their task is to validate The Socioscope projects.

conference.title: The The Socioscope 2021 Conference
conference.intro: The The Socioscope 2021 conference aims to promote the The Socioscope projects and foster the scientific effort around the current Covid-19 pandemic impacts.
conference.project-track-description: to present projects that are already completed, pre-printed or published
conference.wip-track-description: to discuss and support an upcoming or in progress project
conference.cat-intro: We also sort the The Socioscope 2021 conference applications in 5 categories:
conference.other: Other areas relating to the Pandemic

privacy.title: Privacy policy
privacy.text1: TheSocioscope (The Socioscope) website provides a global directory of research projects, surveys and initiatives about the societal and human impacts of the Covid-19 pandemic.
privacy.text10: We do not track users or store any information outside of the project definition scope. A basic and anonymous browser fingerprint is stored only to estimate unique project views and improve our project ranking feature. We do not disclose or sell email addresses or any other personal information. We do not use cookies except for those of
privacy.text2: By registering their project on the The Socioscope website, contributors authorize The Socioscope to publish online the description of their project, except for their personal contact details (email address) which The Socioscope will not share. A “contact” button on the project page enables contributors to receive emails without address disclosure, they are free to share their contact in their reply if they wish.
privacy.text3: Email addresses of contributors are needed to submit a project but they will never be disclosed online nor transferred or sold to any third party. They will be used only:
privacy.text4: to make sure the project is created by a real person (not by a bot)
privacy.text5: to redirect contact requests to contributors through the The Socioscope     servers;
privacy.text6: by the The Socioscope team, to contact contributors to enable their uploads, promote collaborations and occasionally update on The Socioscope;
privacy.text7: by The Socioscope referents, to request edits through The Socioscope servers.
privacy.text8: In compliance with the EU General Data Protection Regulation, you can exert your right to access, correct or oppose the use of your data by contacting

gdpr.checkbox: By ticking this box, I accept that the data collected by the Paris IAS from this form will be processed by the Institute's communication department. It is collected and processed for the purpose of the Institute's communication. The collection of data is compulsory in order to receive the newsletter. The data will not be passed on to third parties. They are kept until the subscriber's request to unsubscribe.
gdpr.text1: In accordance with the French Data Protection Act of 6 January 1978, amended in 2004, and the General Data Protection Regulation, you may exercise your rights of access, rectification and opposition by contacting the Institute at info@The Socioscope.org
gdpr.text2: We use Mailchimp as our marketing platform. By clicking below to subscribe, you acknowledge that your information will be transferred to Mailchimp for processing.

thematics.11: Equality, Diversity Studies and social justice

descriptions.0: Indicate the reason why you block this project
descriptions.1: Piece intended to promote a product, service or organization, or not disclosing author’s affiliation.
descriptions.2: The language and/or content is inappropriate for a research project.
descriptions.3: The relation to the core aim of The Socioscope (social sciences and humanities research on the impacts of the Covid-19 pandemic) is not clear enough.
descriptions.4: Projects should be based on empirical research, or using scientific methods to bring theoretical or methodological advances. Opinion pieces, pamphlets, and commentaries should be published elsewhere.
descriptions.5: Please post one single abstract for a set of similar or connected papers rather than several distinct abstracts. Possibly with a link  to a URL containing the set.
descriptions.6: The submission does not currently reach the threshold of work that would be considered for publication in a peer-reviewed journal.

gentleVersions.0: This piece is intended to promote a product, service or organization, or it does not disclose the affiliation of its author
gentleVersions.3: 'Projects should be based on empirical research, or using scientific methods to bring theoretical or methodological advances. Opinion pieces, pamphlets, and commentaries, however interesting and smart, should be published elsewhere.
gentleVersions.4: Please upload one single contribution for a set of similar or connected papers rather than several distinct abstracts. You can include a link to a URL containing the set.
gentleVersions.5: In its current form, your project has apparent limitations or methodological flaws that need to be dealt with before it can appear in the base.

institutions.eassh: The European Alliance for the Social Sciences and the Humanities was formed in 2015. It is a membership organisation spanning all areas of the humanities and social sciences working to promote these areas of knowledge and research and to engage with relevant policymakers and stakeholders. EASSH has over 50 member organisations including a wide range of disciplinary areas, stakeholders and universities from across Europe.
institutions.ipsp: The International Panel on Social Progress (IPSP) harnesses the competence of about 300 experts worldwide about social issues. It recently delivered a report addressed to all social actors, movements, organizations, politicians and decision-makers, provided them with the best expertise on social change. While the Panel primarily works for the dissemination of knowledge to all relevant actors in society, it also fosters research on the topics it studies and helps to revive interest for research in social long-term prospective analysis.
institutions.isc: The International Science Council (ISC) is a non-governmental organization with a unique global membership that brings together 40 international scientific Unions and Associations and over 140 national and regional scientific organizations including Academies and Research Councils. The ISC was created in 2018 as the result of a merger between the International Council for Science (ICSU, founded in 1931) and the International Social Science Council (ISSC, founded in 1952).It is the only international non-governmental organization bringing together the natural and social sciences and the largest global science organization of its type.
institutions.netias: NetIAS brings together 25 Institutes for Advanced Study across Europe. It was created in 2004 to stimulate a dialogue on IAS practices and possible forms of cooperation. Within the whole network, more than 500 researchers are hosted every year for up to one full academic year. NetIAS members share the objective of creating international and multidisciplinary learning communities. This openness and the freedom the fellows enjoy for their researches serve to promote scientific and intellectual exchanges.
institutions.uai: The UAI is the world organization of national academies in the humanities and social sciences. Its objectives are to initiate, recognize, promote and finance international research projects based on long-term research. Founded in 1919 in Paris with a General Secretariat based in Brussels, the UAI currently comprises more than 100 Academies from 63 countries and all continents.
institutions.ubias: UBIAS stands for “University-Based Institutes for Advanced Study”. Unlike traditional Institutes for Advanced Study, UBIAS institutes are associated with or embedded within a university, and actively contribute to the academic culture and the scientific achievements of their home university. The network now comprises 44 member institutes in 21 countries.
institutions.fmsh: As an international crossroads for Humanities and Social Sciences, the Foundation Maison des Sciences de l'Homme works in synergy with international scientific communities and networks, and fosters collaboration amongst scientific fields.
institutions.nomis: NOMIS’ vision is to “create a spark” in the world of science by enabling and supporting pioneering research in the natural sciences, social sciences and the humanities that benefits humankind and our planet. Our mission is to support and enable insight-driven science across all disciplines, focusing on researchers who put forth bold new ideas, exhibit a pioneering spirit and seek to inspire the world around them.
